qas.question: What percentage of Islamic women were educated before the 1200s?
How many female Islamic scholars were on record after the 1400s?
In what book was a section reserved for the study of Islamic female students?
How many female students were discussed in the al-Daw' al-Iami?
What percentage of Islamic women were educated before the 2000s?
How many female Islamic scholars were on record after the 1600s?
In what book was a section reserved for the study of Islamic male students?
How many male students were discussed in the al-Daw' al-Iami?

context: Prior to the 12th century, women accounted for <a0_0><b4_0>less than one percent<b4_0/><a0_0/> of the world’s Islamic scholars. However, al-Sakhawi and Mohammad Akram Nadwi have since found evidence of <a1_0><b5_0>over 8,000<b5_0/><a1_0/> female scholars since the 15th century. al-Sakhawi devotes an entire volume of his 12-volume biographical dictionary <a2_0><b6_0>al-Ḍawʾ al-lāmiʻ<b6_0/><a2_0/> to female scholars, giving information on <a3_0><b7_0>1,075<b7_0/><a3_0/> of them. More recently, the scholar Mohammad Akram Nadwi, currently a researcher from the Oxford Centre for Islamic Studies, has written 40 volumes on the muḥaddithāt (the women scholars of ḥadīth), and found at least 8,000 of them.
